body_html:
@trias702 It'll be just the same without Ninja. The actual backend is MSVC 2017.
The current directory will be switched in torch\lib\build_libs.bat to torch\lib\build\ATen and then the CMake will start. The write function(Line 108) of the python script aten\src\ATen\gen.py will be called to generate the real headers. So the files will be there after gen.py is called. You can try calling gen.py when the current folder is torch\lib\build\ATen to see if it works.
body_text:
@trias702 It'll be just the same without Ninja. The actual backend is MSVC 2017.
The current directory will be switched in torch\lib\build_libs.bat to torch\lib\build\ATen and then the CMake will start. The write function(Line 108) of the python script aten\src\ATen\gen.py will be called to generate the real headers. So the files will be there after gen.py is called. You can try calling gen.py when the current folder is torch\lib\build\ATen to see if it works.
body:
@trias702 It'll be just the same without Ninja. The actual backend is MSVC 2017.
The current directory will be switched in `torch\lib\build_libs.bat` to `torch\lib\build\ATen` and then the CMake will start. The `write` function(Line 108) of the python script `aten\src\ATen\gen.py` will be called to generate the real headers. So the files will be there after gen.py is called. You can try calling gen.py when the current folder is `torch\lib\build\ATen` to see if it works.
